item.title: Polyester, another configuration management tool
item.description:
I’ve been getting back into what’s now called the small internet, and find myself yet again managing server configurations, deployments, and secrets. Starting out with a kubernetes cluster, which has great tooling for cluster management, I quickly found that I didn’t want to pay the compute cost of a running cluster. My ideal cluster is as cheap as possible and basically ephemeral, with a short process for bootstrapping machines that restores the previous backed up state and updates dns.

Kubernetes is nice because it scales down well, easily running all my little workloads on a single machine. However systemd scales down just fine too, while avoiding the heavy runtime cost and OCI requirements of kube, as well as providing a set of security controls that I’m interested in learning more about (and some nice bells and whistles like systemd-socket-proxy as well).

Ansible is a fine choice for managing clusters like this, but I prefer a DSL written in a language I already tend to use frequently when I’m managing servers. So, after a bit of looking, I decided to write my own tool, because I’m like that.

polyester

It’s called polyester, and I think its neat. Here are some of its goals:

  1. A simple implementation. It should be easy enough to understand what it’s doing from reading the documentation, trying it out, and reading the source code.

  2. Decoupled transport. Run it over ssh, git, or http.

  3. Versioned change tracking. Preview changes by running the tool.

  4. Conducive to managing servers, mostly involving file management, scripts, and secrets. But there are more complicated things too that should have solutions – users, CA certificates, reloads vs restarts, etc.

  5. Not trying to invent something brand new or over-abstract. I’d just like to write something like a set of shell scripts to manage my server.

Currently I have a working tool, more or less, enough to keep track of my config files and secrets without getting in the way too much. However it’s in an experimental state and not close to ready for public consumption :)

My process for building it was to make a tool that felt like an extension of the shell scripts that can often become much of a cluster’s infrastructure, becoming a maintenance burden because of loss of understanding, complexity of implementation, and other reasons. But where shell scripts become over-complex as they grow and are iterated on, by adding an organization structure for additional data and parameters, maybe polyester can avoid some of that late-term complexity.

With that out of the way, here’s an example of how its looking so far. This is a plan file that manages a great IRC bouncer called soju:

#!/bin/sh
set -eu

repodir=/home/appuser/repos/soju
appdir=/home/appuser/apps/soju

P git-repo https://git.sr.ht/~emersion/soju $repodir

P sh --dir $repodir \
    --on-change $repodir \
    --target /usr/local/bin/soju \
    "make && make install"

P mkdir -m 0700 $appdir
P pcopy soju.conf run.sh $appdir/
P pcopy "systemd/*" /etc/systemd/system/

P sh --target "$appdir/{soju.conf,run.sh}" "chown -R appuser:appuser $appdir"

P sh \
    --target "/etc/letsencrypt/{live,archive}/soju.autonomist.club"

setfacl -R -m u:appuser:rX /etc/letsencrypt/live
setfacl -R -m u:appuser:rX /etc/letsencrypt/archive

setfacl -R -m u:appuser:rX /etc/letsencrypt/live/soju.autonomist.club
setfacl -R -m u:appuser:rX /etc/letsencrypt/archive/soju.autonomist.club

P sh \
    --on-change /usr/local/bin/soju \
    --on-change "$appdir/{soju.conf,run.sh}" \
    "systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl restart soju.service"

What’s happening here hopefully looks somewhat familiar (assuming you’re somewhat experienced with shell scripting and linux server management):

  1. We declare a git repository targeting a repository directory. Polyester updates to HEAD when it runs.
  2. If the repository had changes, rebuild and install soju.
  3. Copy configuration and system files, do stuff with files.
  4. Restart soju if there were any changes.

Files like this, bundled together with other data (config files, secrets) typically bundled in a git repository, makes a plan. Plans run together concurrently, taking dependencies into account. Plans are made up of operations that are run on the environment where polyester apply is run, such as “copy files from the plan”, “render a template containing decrypted secrets to this file”, “run this shell when these files change, but only signal change if this specific file changes”, etc. Shell functions can be used to parameterize a set of operations. All together, this provides a lot.

implementation

Behind the curtain, polyester “compiles” the operations by executing the script with some small transformations. Each operation, when executed in this declaration mode, prints its name and arguments into to a (YAML ðŸ˜¬) plan declaration file. This is the file that is used when applying changes. Then the plan declarations are read and plan execution begins. This involves conditional execution, depending on previous, current, and desired state. The solution for this leverages an interface that provides a few abstractions on top of [spf13/cobra] to read state, determine how changes are determined, and of course to execute the state change. Operations are executed in order, only if it or any previous operations detected or triggered a change. Finally, some state files are saved into the file system to be used by the next run.

From here, I’m planning to add explicit change triggering, so you can changes for different purposes, such as running systemctl reload instead of systemctl restart. I’m also planning separate apply “phases”, to better sequence file changes from deploys – ie first make file changes for all plans, then run systemd reloads/restarts one at a time. In general it would be nice to be able to preview, check, and execute a change on some hosts using polyester over ssh, though it’s easy enough to run ssh myhost "cd cluster && git pull && polyester check && polyester apply" for now.

The current architecture should be suitable for supporting many languages beyond POSIX shell and bash, which could be fun. The current implementation should also be suitable for building various static analysis to let the tool help ensure consistent, secure environments.

You might notice some magic in the plan above. Sometimes the P sh is called with a shell script in argument form, other times there are no arguments, followed by lines of shell. Using the great mvdan/sh package, I was able to parse the shell script, and do an intermediate transformation to wrap the shell lines in an EOF string. This is nice where it’s working, which is sadly not everywhere, such as in function bodies, because my editor highlights it like a normal shell script. Hopefully there are only small issues in the way of this working everywhere!

that’s all

It’s been fun working on polyester, but also like most projects, its now looking more difficult than I expected it would be when I started. As the ideal solutions become clear, and how the state management, operations, and dsl can work together harmoniously, the real work involved in achieving the goals I set out to accomplish became apparent.

If you think this is interesting, maybe you should email me!

item.title: Wrangling 15 Years of Email
item.description:
• export promotions label mbox from google
  • train spam
  • train ham
# train spam
bogofilter --unicode=false -svM < spam.mbox
notmuch search --output files --format text0 -- tag:spam | xargs -0 bogofilter --unicode=false -svB

# train ham
notmuch search --output files --format text0 -- tag:friend or tag:family or tag:list or tag:ham and not tag:spam | xargs -0 bogofilter --unicode=false -nvB

after the first run:

$ notmuch search --output files --format text0 -- tag:inbox | xargs -0 bogofilter -BT | tee bogo.1.out
$ cat bogo.1.out | awk '{print $(NF-1)}' | sort | uniq -c
  23729 H
  17253 S
  26983 U

spam-check.py tag:inbox

had a lot of false positives. rewrote in go, better subprocess communication:

$ cat bogo.2.out | awk '{print $1}' | sort | uniq -c
  21975 HAM
      1 <noreply@h4.hilton.com>
   8339 SPAM
  18477 UNSURE

ran in 6 minutes.

jeff@x1cats:~ $ cat bogo.3.out | awk '{print $1}' | sort | uniq -c
  25931 HAM
      1 <noreply@h4.hilton.com>
   4854 SPAM
  17922 UNSURE
jeff@x1cats:~ $ cat bogo.4.out | awk '{print $1}' | sort | uniq -c
  26350 HAM
      1 <noreply@h4.hilton.com>
   4744 SPAM
  16755 UNSURE
  • bindings in aerc so i can mark spam/ham and train bogofilter
  • train bogo in post proc: if it comes in as spam / ham, etc
  • post proc: apply bogo to unknown emails

basically the system supports:

  • tag spam/ham in bulk using notmuch
  • zoom in and tag using aerc
  • train bogo using gmail’s spam detection as it comes in
  • train gmail using bogofilter by pushing the spam back out
  • audit bogofilter by having it set intermediate tags (bogo-spam, bogo-unsure, bogo-ham)

inbox: out of ~13k messages, 5000 were spam

inspiration

item.title: OS Customization Is for You
item.description:
I got a new, modern laptop recently. This time around, I moved back to linux from OSX. Containerized workloads in particular for me have been annoying me on OSX for a while. Linux is generally a better OS if you are spending a lot of your time writing and building code that mostly runs on servers. OSX is generally fine about this, but everywhere I’ve worked, there’s always one application that has a large enough codebase to cause filesystem slowness to become frustrating. Most of my time on computers is spent between a terminal and a browser, so I don’t have particularly complex workflows. Warning: This post likely wont be very interesting to you, unless you are interested in computers and customizing your laptop, or maybe you dislike customization and want to explore why by following along.

It’s definitely true that compared to OSX, setting up linux takes a lot of time. It takes 2 hours to set up a macbook because the defaults are mostly the best. There are annoying differences between darwin and linux, but it’s easy enough to work around them, and because the overall experience is good, it’s just fundamentally out of your way to extent you stop noticing over time. That’s a huge benefit to OSX, and linux just doesn’t have that property. Buying a computer with linux preinstalled may help somewhat, but overall, you’ll likely need to expend some energy to find a suitable configuration.

If you use linux, you may as well just commit to do some tweaking. That can be as little as bootstrapping configuration files and installing some preferred applications, through to installing a modified kernel. In a few days you can create a more or less bootstrap-capable, more or less optimal workflow for yourself, and while there is wisdom in keeping tweaks minimal so muscle memory translates to different machines, your laptop is still the primary means through which many of us are using computers.

So I decided to spend a few days doing tweaks, mostly porting the few common workflows I have over from OSX, or replacing them with a reasonable alternative. I ended up spending the most time playing with nerd fonts and tmux. I made my terminal bar look something like my menu bar. Here is the menu bar:

Here is the terminal bar:

They have some similarities, at least in how its components are placed. The terminal status has a lot more going on than the desktop. It’s easier for me to get to a menu bar I like in the terminal, since it’s just a line of characters, plus I spend a lot more time there, so that is better for me. Nerd fonts are nice here, since real estate is at a premium, and the icons are unobtrusive (read: not distracting). In particular, it’s easy to see, at a glance, what’s happening in a tab. If a program is running, there’s a little Tux to the left of it. If it’s running as root, there’s a cube. If I’m in a directory with a git repository, there’s an icon for that too. The clock and battery indicator are very useful for me, since I usually work in a fullscreen terminal, and can lose track of the time. It’s easy to go from here to integrating a pomodoro timer, or any other tool. Last, the CPU and memory indicators are cute, and I’ve found they come in handy from time to time.

To do this customization, I used a combination of plugins, other peoples hacks, and my own hacks:

  • a patched font
  • a fallback font for nerd fonts, supported by the terminal (kitty)
  • tmux plugins
  • shell configuration
  • forking a tmux theme (gruvbox!)
  • writing a small graphing tool

That’s a lot that needs to work together. I get that’s not for everyone! There are easier ways to get this all working than what I did. For example, there are plenty of fonts that don’t need to be patched in order to work nicely with kitty. Kitty by itself could probably handle a lot of what tmux does too. There are surely plenty of already existing tools to print unicode graphs. All of these things can also be done using other terminals or window managers, in many cases likely with less configuration. All I can really say to that is, I leveraged the tools I like to use so I can use them according to muscle and visual memory. It’s pretty tailored to me specifically, meaning it works according to my principles for computer work and play.

If, for some reason, you don’t write code, and you’re still reading, here is where your eyes will really glaze over. I’m going to show some code I used to get some of the more custom behavior out of this setup. In order to accomplish the title updates for directory change or program execution, here’s what I did in ~/.bashrc. First, to handle updating the title when commands are executed:

# runs before command runs
tmux_prompt_hook() {
    if [[ "$BASH_COMMAND" != "$PROMPT_COMMAND" ]]; then
        prefix="<nerdfont tux icon> "
        out="$(echo "$BASH_COMMAND" | awk '{print $1;}')"
        case $out in
            vi|vim)
                prefix=""
                out="<nerdfont vim icon>"
                ;;
            sudo)
                prefix="<nerdfont cube icon> "
                out="$(echo "$BASH_COMMAND" | awk '{print $2;}')"
                ;;
            hub)
                out="git"
                ;;
        esac

        # send ANSI code that tmux uses to update the title
        echo -ne "\033k${prefix}${out}\033\\"
    fi
}

# update window titles in tmux
if [[ "$TMUX" != "" ]]; then
    # PROMPT_COMMAND triggers before printing the prompt
    export PROMPT_COMMAND='$HOME/bin/tmux-prompt-command.sh'

    # DEBUG trap triggers before the command's process is started
    trap tmux_prompt_hook DEBUG
fi

Here’s a useful function to point the trap at if you want to better understand how this works:

dump_stuff() {
    echo "comp_line: $COMP_LINE"
    echo "BASH_COMMAND: $BASH_COMMAND"
    echo "PROMPT_COMMAND: $PROMPT_COMMAND"
}

I wrote tinygraph to render the CPU and memory graphs. Tired of having to hunt around whenever I need a solution for this, I wanted a tool I could use to make arbitrary graphs with threshold coloring with easily customizable characters. Here’s the sort of thing you can do with it:

cpu=$((100-$(vmstat 1 2|tail -1|awk '{print $15}')))

TMUX_STATUS=1 tinygraph -n "$cpu" -t 100 \
    --prefix "<nerdfont cpu icon>" \
    --graph equal \
    --threshold '60:fg=yellow,bold' \
    --threshold '83:fg=red,bold'

# see what's built in and play with thresholds by running: tinygraph --workout

Customization is a large topic, and this post describes a tiny part of it. There is a lot computer folks can do in this space to automate away toil and provide useful experiences for ourselves and others. What that means is strongly contested, but nonetheless there is potential to make a significant impact on our relationship the the machines we use.

item.title: Mass Media Coverage in the Early Democratic Primary 2020 Election
item.description:
New transparency rules in Iowa have shed new light on the election process, and in doing so have also exposed how major media outlets influence the process, favoring and disfavoring specific candidates. At the same time, major media themselves have engaged in election rigging to an even greater degree than in 2016, while independent journalists and other individuals have tracked election innaccuracies to a greater degree than previously possible.

Several articles have come out describing how the media has framed the election to favor Pete Buttigieg [1][2]. Others describe the recent election in Bolivia, in which US government officials called for intervention [3] on the grounds that the results of the election were delayed (cites) [4]. This type of influence media exerts on the 2020 Democratic Primary is neither fair, nor a conspiracy, just a banal continuation of US major media in a steady state.

grand conspiracies

As of the time of this writing, there are still many inaccurate results after the election has officially closed [5]. It also appears there are many errors that are now impossible to correct [6]. Much of this work is done by independent and local journalists, not the major media so far, despite some honest admissions by them that the election process made no sense [7]. We can safely say at this point that the Iowa Democratic Caucus was an electoral blunder of world-historical proportions.

These events raise questions:

  • Why were “State Delegate Equivalents” the means Iowa Democrats chose to use, given the popular vote totals now being publicly available? I feel like candidates losing despite winning the popular vote is something we don’t like.

  • Why were the television media running banners all week declaring a winner when the results weren’t even in yet?

  • Why did Iowa Democrats choose to release 62% of the results instead of just waiting until the counts were completed?

  • Why did Iowa Democrats choose to stop the count when there were clearly errors being reported in the media?

  • What are the actual, correct results, as far as we can possibly tell?

These are not unreasonable, tinfoil-hat questions. They are questions we reasonably expect the media to ask. I hope to see some good explanations of a timeline of the caucus and as close an approximation to the correct result soon.

the spin

Examples abound for those looking for proof of media spin. Take this chart from CNN:

Professional! I’m definitely just an amateur, but that chart sure looks to be using logarithmic smoothing to me. That kind of smoothing would move all the values closer to each other, which seems unhelpful for understanding differences in campaign spend. Lets see what it would look like without that:

Looks a little different, huh? But we can do better. I don’t want to tell CNN how to do their job, but pies are making for good content about money lately:

You’re seeing that right: the billionaires are outspending the rest of the candidates combined by at least 5:1. I’d love to see the chart of the amount of billionaire money spent next to comparable newsroom yearly revenues.

Much social media discourse follows major outlet talking points, such as focus on the SDE vote count, but also generally being focused on vote totals. However no one seriously believes the vote itself is what the Iowa caucus is about. The Iowa caucus is about setting a momentum for the rest of the primary.

And let’s not forget Facebook, they managed to circulate disinformation about Iowa for an entire day, with the correction being shared at a relatively pitiable rate.

it is likely that the caucus results were manipulated in a similar manner in 2016.

At the end of the day, you have over here millions of people emphatically supporting Bernie Sanders, donating to his campaign to a historically unprecedented degree, and over there you have nearly the entire mass media conglomerate in unison attacking him, and have been doing so for the past five years. It’s getting harder to disagree with Sanders when he says the billionaires hate him, and their masks are off in this primary.

I leave you with this most divisive graphic, widely panned as “the most antisemitic cartoon I’ve ever seen about an Episcopalian [9]:”

  2. Jim Naureckas. (February 5, 2020). How Corporate Media Make Pete Look Like Heâ€™s Winning.
  3. US Senate (116th Congress). (January 8, 2020). S.Res.447.
  4. Kevin Cashman (Jacobin). (February 5, 2020). If Iowa Was Bolivia, the US Would Have Already Intervened.
  5. Daniel Nichanian (@Taniel) (The Appeal). Tweet. (February 9, 2020).

16-bit Intel 8088 chip

with an Apple Macintosh
you can't run Radio Shack programs
in its disc drive.
nor can a Commodore 64
drive read a file
you have created on an
IBM Personal Computer.
both Kaypro and Osborne computers use
the CP/M operating system
but can't read each other's
handwriting
for they format (write
on) discs in different
ways.
the Tandy 2000 runs MS-DOS but
can't use most programs produced for
the IBM Personal Computer
unless certain
bits and bytes are
altered
but the wind still blows over
Savannah
and in the Spring
the turkey buzzard struts and
flounces before his
hens.
